content:
Renault puts a V6
rocket in your pocket.

And which takes
longer to change,
a gearbox or a woman's outfit?

Hello. Now, the show tonight
is mostly about blokishness.
You know the sort of thing,

we won't ask directions, we
won't read instruction manuals.

We have a sound recordist,
okay?

Rolled up on a shoot the other
day, front of his car all stoved in.

Said he'd been on the M6 in
a queue of slow-moving traffic

and he was a bit bored,
so he wondered

would it be possible to drive
with your legs crossed?

Now, no woman
would ever do that.

And it's much the same story
with understeer and oversteer.

I've never had a letter from a
girl saying what's the difference.

But we've had loads of letters
from blokes asking.

So, over now to Richard
Hammond in the science corner.

Thank you, Jeremy. Now,
this is really quite simple. Okay?
Understeer works like this.

You drive down the road, you turn
the wheel, but the car goes straight on,

crashes into a tree,
and you die.
Oversteer works like this.

You drive down the same
bit of road, turn the wheel,

but the back of the car
comes round like this,

and you go off the road,
crash into a tree, and you die.

Now, oversteer is best, because
you don't see the tree that kills you.
I understand that.
Now as a general rule,

front-wheel-drive cars
understeer,

and rear-wheel-drive cars
oversteer.

But there's always been
one car

where you never knew
what it was going to do.
The Porsche 911.
See, unlike a Ferrari,

the engine is not in the
middle, it's right here in the back.
That upsets the balance.

It's like a horse, or as Porsche
would call it, a horse-a pushing a cart.

You know why it was
called a 911, don't you?

So the Americans would know
what to dial when they crashed.

And they would crash.
It's a very scary car.

And the scariest model
of them all
is the Turbo.

A woman would have
moved the engine,

but because Porsche's
run by men,

they've spent
the last 40 years

stubbornly trying to engineer
their way around the problem.

To be honest,
they've cracked it.

The modern-day Turbo, like
this one, has four-wheel drive,

and perhaps the most
sorted chassis of any road car.

And because the engine
is still at the back,

pressing down like a big,
heavy lump on the rear wheels,

you get tons and tons of grip,
and tons and tons of traction.

I said a couple of years ago that a
911 Turbo is better than a Ferrari 355,

and I'll stand by that.
It's wonderful.

Amazing car.
Now, completely sorted.

- Hang on.
- What? What?

- That's not the end. No, that's not...
- Yes, we've seen enough.

- We've seen enough.
- I'm absolutely confident...

Who would like to see what
happens next in that film?
Yes!
Roll it.

- So, you spun it, then?
- I spun it slightly.

What do you mean, "slightly"?
How can you slightly spin?

That's like saying, "I slightly
fell off a ladder this morning."

The... The problem is, is that when
you're driving a Ferrari or a Lamborghini,
they constantly say to you,

"I'm gonna kill you, I'm gonna
stick a knife in your heart,

"I'm gonna turn it around."
Whereas the 911, okay,

the Turbo, it's saying,
"It's okay."

Lulls you into this false
sense of security.

You think
it's an ordinary car.

It's like a circus lion. That's
the best way to look at it.

You go, "Oh, look at that, it's
jumping through hoops, isn't it docile."
It's still a lion!

It's still a 420
horsepower supercar!

You have got to be
a superhuman driver

to get the best out of one
of these, and I'm not one.

And neither are you,
but luckily,
I know a man who is.

So, off the line, and even with massive
traction the Porsche spins its wheels.
It really is wet out there.

Will the Hammerhead defeat
the Porsche's huge grip?

Yes, he's a bit sideways. In
the dry, in this car, there would be

a chance of beating
the mighty Zonda,

but the rain's doing it
no favours at all.
Squirmy underbraking there.

Now, through the first sector,
he's already a massive

five seconds down
on the Zonda's time.

He'll struggle to make that up
in the second half.

Into the Follow Through,
just a dab of brakes...

Now, he's coming down to the penultimate.
The Zonda lapped him 1:23 in the last series.

The Porsche will never
match that in this weather.

How close can he get through
Gambon, and across the line in...
One minute, 31 dead.

So, where does that go?
Let's have a look. 31 is...

- Here.
- There, above the M3.

Now, if you take
four seconds off, which is

basically what happens if you
want to get a dry time, that's 1:27.

- That's faster than the Murcielago.
- Yeah.

That is a great car,
if you know what you're doing.

And now there's a version
for those who don't.

This is the diet
911 Turbo.

The one-cal, low-fat version
they call the C4S.

It looks pretty much the same as a Turbo,
with the flared wheel arches and the spoilers.

And it has exactly
the same grippy chassis,

the same four-wheel-drive
system, the same brakes

and the same
sports suspension.

It even has the same flat six
3.6 litre engine as the Turbo.
Except there's no turbo.

This, then,
is an ordinary 911.
A plain and simple Carrera 4
in a He-Man suit.

You know what this is,
don't you?

It's the Porsche
neo-Georgian house.

All the looks, but without the
18th-century killer plumbing.
And it's fine.

If you like
that sort of thing.
It's interesting.

The engine sounds at its best when
you're going 14 miles an hour. Town speed.

Posing speeds,
when people are looking.

As soon as you get out
in the countryside,

build up a bit speed,
it all settles down again.

By losing the turbo, the brake
horsepower figure falls from 420 to 320.
320's still a lot, though.

So, it's still a fast car,
0 to 60 in 5.1 seconds.
A top speed of 174.
It's not scary fast, though.

It's not like going to the pub
with a murderer.

You're not thinking, "This is
fun, but soon I will be dead."

There's another
advantage, too.

The Turbo costs 88,000,
and this is 63,000.
That's a saving of £25,000.
But...

I don't know. I mean, yes,
it's a wonderful car,

be in no doubt,
and it's a Porsche.

So, you can do 100,000 miles
and it will never go wrong,

use it in the snow,
and the wind and the drizzle.
I do respect its abilities.

But you can have
all those abilities
in a Carrera 4 for £60,000.
Why pay more for a fake?

Earlier on in the series, we launched
a search for Britain's biggest car bore.

And we received literally quite a few
letters, some of which were very good.

But one of them
was simply outstanding.
This is Robert Lynn.

This is his Sierra, on his
drive, and this is his house.

It's all pretty
standard stuff.

Then there's a living room in
here, kitchen, usual sort of stuff.
Uh, cupboards. Bread bin.
That's odd.
Microwave.
Car. As, uh, as you do.

So, Robert, um,
I've got to ask.

- Yeah.
- Why is it in the kitchen?

Well, I started
to design it there.

I sketched it out on a piece
of cardboard on the floor.

Then the metal got
laid on that.

A few bits got welded up,
and one thing led to another.

And there it is.
Well, what is it, though?

It's to be used for drag
racing sprints and hill climbs,

and we're actually gonna do some
speed records with this, as well.

- That's a pretty serious piece of kit.
- Yes, yes, yeah.

- It's not like a kit car.
- No.

- Does it work?
- Yes, yes. Do you want me to show you?
Yeah, cool.

There's a degree
of fire hazard to this.

- I've got a fire extinguisher here.
- Cool.

Do you want to take
the safety wedge out?

- There's a yellow wedge...
- Oh, it's here.
Right. Okay.

Yeah, that's just
squeezing going on.

- Oh, you're gonna blow that through?
- Yep.

Right, I'll put the...
I'll hold the...
I'll stand over here.
How often do you fire it up?

Not that often,
because of the, um...

Potential for
something peculiar.
Peculiar?
Right. Yeah.

Still, I've got the
safety wedge out.

- So, we're all right here.
- Yeah.

If it does catch fire, just aim it
and spray it at the carburettor.

This thing's full of water,
as well.

- This thing there...
- You have a kettle full of water there?
Yeah. Yeah.
That's fantastic!

It blew this piece of the
skirting board off there! Look.

The exhaust against there blew
the skirting board off the wall.
It's running a bit rich.

Quite close to
your fire there, as well.

Yes, I've turned the gas off
at the mains, I did that first.
Yeah, that'd be best.

Thing is,
it doesn't end there.

This is a kitchen, and this is a
kitchen door, and this is a car.
Kitchen door, car.

You can see where
this is going, can't you?

He can't get it out
of the kitchen.

I mean, really,
won't go through the door.

So, is he going to
take the car apart?
No.
That was perfect, that was.

You must have known
it wasn't going to come out.

Well, when you've
gone past a certain stage,

it just sort of gets its own
momentum, doesn't it, sort of thing.

There's always distractions, and you'd
go in, work in the back room as a hobby.

Just to take your mind off
other things at work, you know?

And you just, after
a few years of doing it...

- So, it sat out like a jigsaw puzzle on the kitchen floor.
- Yeah.

- Same sort of thing. But bigger.
- Yeah. Yeah.

What was it like
working in there, though?

It's pretty good working
conditions, really. It's ideal.

It's as warm and dry as the
house, 'cause it is the house, so,
brilliant.

Um, I wonder if someone
could stand on the ramp there?
Is there any danger?
Uh, no.

- Excellent.
- Is there any danger?
Okay.
And so there it is.

Free at last,
and ready to go racing.

So, let's just get
one thing straight.

Did he know when he started to build the car
that it would never come out of the kitchen?
No, not when he started.

That's the point.
He got partway through,

and then presumably late at night,
spannering away, he was looking up,

and he said this, he realised
it wasn't going to go out,

but he carried on. I dunno. It was
warm in there to work, and he liked it.

I presume there's no wife
involved in this?

No, well...
There was, but unlike the car,

the wife did fit through
the door quite nicely.
Fairly early on.

Okay, well, now, listen, if you
know someone who is more...
Mental?

Well, committed, shall we say,
to the world of cars,
write to us, please, at, uh...

What should we call it,
this week? I know.
Uh, now.

Since this programme tonight
is mostly about blokes,

we thought we'd have a guest
who wasn't one.

She is in fact the second richest
ginger-haired Liverpudlian woman in Britain.

Ladies and gentlemen,
Anne Robinson!
Hi, Anne, how are you?

- Are you well? Have a seat.
- I will.
I, uh...

I hope the same person
who worked out my wealth
hasn't done the lap timings.

Well, why? Are you
claiming that Cilla is...

I'm just saying, I hope
the person who worked out

- that I was, uh, second...
- Behind her?

Well, she has just bought
a Ferrari, you know?

Mind you, it wouldn't go
with her hair.

That's what I mean,
red hair and...

I mean, orange hair
and a red car.
I'd never buy a red car.

- No, not you!
- Don't you think?

Actually, anyone who's ever
owned a red Ferrari is a plonker?

Do you know,
I don't, actually.

- I, no...
- You wouldn't dream of it, would you?

- I wouldn't dream of such a thing.
- No.
Now, if you're so rich
as you claim to be,

why do you have
such a crummy car?

- Do I have a crummy car?
- You have a Mercedes SL.

- I'm sorry.
- Jeremy, Jeremy, I'm sorry,
that is Penrose's.

- Your husband? Yeah.
- Yes.

And if you're going to get
into one of these

conversations
'cause you've got...
The superior model.

- Yes, so what you're saying...
- The better model.

So what you're saying is, our car
has a smaller penis than your car.
Yeah.
Tell me this...
Yeah?

To be fair, don't you find
the really joyful thing

about both the cars
is that...

You know when
you're stuck in a traffic jam?

- Mmm-hmm.
- Isn't it great fun to watch the telly?

I haven't had
the television put in.

- Oh, you don't have a television in yours!
- No.

But mine's so fast, I can get home
in time to watch the programme.
You bought the wrong car.

- Sorry.
- I didn't buy it.

Well, your husband's bought...
Is he here?

- Yes. He is.
- Where is he?
Penrose!

Loitering in the back.
There he is.
You've bought the wrong car!

What do you think when blokes
are blokish about cars?

I can't understand. It's like women
discussing their nail polish. Isn't it?

I mean, it doesn't matter. You
just get in a car and you drive it!

- No.
- That's all there is to be said.

- Watch TV in your car.
- Yeah.

So, I mean, for instance,
these books here that we've got.

Road Vehicle Aerodynamic
Design, by RH Barnard.

I'm presuming that's not
Rebecca Barnard, is it?

And this one, as well. This is from
my library. This is my favourite book.

How To Rebuild
Big-Block Chevy Engines.

This presumably isn't the sort of
thing that you'd have in your house.

No, no. I tell you, if Penrose...
Penrose has to cover

what I call Penrose porn,
which is the car magazines.
"Penrose porn."

And if he brought home
Big-Block Chevy Engines,

I'd have to readjust his
medication, because he...

- What, his Chateauneuf du Pape?
- Yes, yes.

Let's test out
your blokiness.

- Okay.
- Do you ever ask for directions?

Oh, we've got sat nav now.
But I would. Yes.

- You do ask for directions?
- Yes.

Now, you see... Have we got any men
here at all today? One or two, I suppose.

- Has any man here ever asked for directions?
- No, that's a silly question.

- No.
- No, never.

- Why do you think we don't?
- Never.

I think, you can't bear
to let us think...
See, what Penrose does is,

he keeps pretending he knows
where we're going.

- Mmm. Yeah.
- That's what it is.

And also the other thing is, when
you've got the map on your knee,

and you're very carefully
telling him where to go,

you look up, and he's just made a
decision. He's never seen the map.
Just out of nowhere.

- Yes, I have.
- And even, can I tell you, it gets worse,

because we've now got
sat nav in most of our cars.
And...
That the, um...

- Was that a silly thing to say? Probably.
- No, I love that.
"In most of our cars."

Anyway, you know we call her
Audrey Hepburn?

- Who? Oh, the woman in the...
- The sat nav.

- Yeah.
- We were in Dijon last week,

and the sat nav... We'd never
been to Dijon before,

so Penrose cannot possibly
know anything about Dijon!
And we get to a roundabout,

and it says,
"Take the second..."

She says, "Take the
second turning on the left."

And he says,
"It's the first one."
That is like...

'Cause there are a number of
these statistics that one comes across.

The difference between
men and women on the road.

Now, apparently,
I have one here.

"Men are distracted by a girl
on a pavement 42 times a week."

"Girls are only distracted
17 times."

Yes, but there's all the times
the girls are looking at shoe shops,
that hasn't been taken in.

28% of men say they've had sex
in a car, but only 20% of women.

Men think a car is four times
more important than women

for pulling, basically attracting
a member of the opposite sex.

- Is that resonant with you?
- No.

- You never...
- It's actually what guys never get the hang of.

I mean,
what guys should do
is go... If they want to pull,

they need to go out with a guy
who is very talkative,

very showy,
very flash, and say nothing.

That's the best way
to pull a girl.

That would explain everything
for all my friends.
So, so, actually...
So, actually,

the car should be
very understated.

- Really? Yeah. Dirty...
- Can we show you...

Understated, preferably
with a dog in the back.

- That's an attractive proposition?
- Yes. Very, very attractive.

We've got some cars parked outside.
We'd like you to have a look at it,

and tell us whether you
think... Is this an attractive sight?
Good-looking guy...

That's a guy without
a girlfriend, isn't it?

Well, yes. I would actually
agree with you on that. I mean...

- So, you're not a fan of that sort of thing?
- No.

- The Evo 8. Is it...
- Not if they're over 18.

Let's have a look at
the next one, then.

That won't do, then, chaps. If you've
got an Evo 8, you're not gonna... A-ha!

I quite like that. That's an
Audi 4 Quattro, isn't it? Coupe.

- TT. "Titty," as I like to call it.
- Well, don't be picky with me!

No, fair... I'm just giving
you the real names.

No, I do actually quite
like, um... I quite like that.

- I think that's quite cool.
- Now, that's odd, because on our cool wall,

we've got it as
not even remotely cool.

No, but I know
what I'm talking about.

I'll be sure to move it,
uh, later on.

Um, okay, next.
Oh, now, there we are.

- Now, that's a Mazda MX5.
- It is. Isn't it?
It's his sister's, I bet.

- A bit of a girly car, that, we think.
- I think, not a bit of.
Completely, utterly...
Girly car.

Not even a hairdresser's car, it's the
receptionist of the hairdresser's car!
Have we got any more cars?

Yes, there we go. Look
now. That's a Jeep Wrangler.

- Attractive? Would you find...
- It's okay.

It's a good run around
in the country, isn't it?

- Uh, no, actually.
- Isn't it?
No, that's shocking.

- Appalling things. Plus...
- No good in the snow or anything?

Well,
it's better than cycling,

- but, you know.
- Yeah.
Now, um...

- Obviously, you're not just here to discuss all this.
- No.

You're here
to see how fast...

You can drive our reasonably
priced car round the track.
Um, how do you think you did?

I mean, down here at the
bottom we've got Harry Enfield,

up at the top
we've got Jay Kay.

I'd... I'd be terribly pleased
if I beat Boris.

- Boris Johnson, at one minute 56.
- Yeah.

- Shall we find out?
- Yeah!
Let's have a look.

Now,
that's a racing start.

I've got to be faster than
Harry. I've done that again.
Stayed in first.

Not that you're
a determined person.

And I've got to
put my foot down.

Over, over, over, over, over,
over, over, over, over.

- Over what?
- Well, just what he told me.

A bit too tight,
I would suggest, but...

- Who'd like to know how fast that was?
- I would like to.

- Yes!
- More than anybody, you would.
And this is the great thing,

is that most people come and
you think they're not gonna care,

they're all big celebs, but
actually can see it in their faces.

You did it,
and you wanted to beat...

- Boris. Yeah.
- Well, Boris at 1:56?

You did it in one minute,
57 seconds.
Just!
I didn't beat Boris.

- I'm really down the bottom.
- You were only a second off Boris's time.
Yeah, but Michael Gambon?

- Michael Gambon's a lunatic. He's an absolute maniac!
- Tara Palmer, whatever...

He's the fastest, maddest
driver I've seen in my life.

- He's 124...
- I want to go round again now.

You're welcome to go out
there again.

- Have another bash again...
- Jamie Oliver?

- I know.
- I've done so badly!

- You haven't done badly.
- I have! I'm third bottom.

Well, that's 'cause... We've been
doing the series for only about,
how many is this? 15 weeks.

- We've had all the people...
- Don't you try and placate me.

- I've done really badly.
- These are people who are...

- Ross Kemp, for goodness' sake.
- Ross Kemp...
Oh. I'll never live this down.

I can't go back to
Gloucestershire.

Why, Ross Kemp's not in
Gloucestershire.

I promise he'll be down in the
East End, beating a few geezers up.

I see people still laugh at him for
doing what he thinks is so badly.
He only wants to come back.

But these, like Gordon Ramsay,
are mad, keen car petrolheads!
Right.

So I think that was a very
good time,

- and I think you have been huge sport.
- Why are you being nice to me?

Because you're a lovely lady
and I adore you.

But I'd like to thank you
very much for coming.

Ladies and gentlemen,
Annie Robinson.

You sit down,
I've got a quick thing to do.
Right. The news.

And uh, we're feeling a bit
remiss this week.

Because we like to think on Top
Gear we're across what's happening

in the world of cars,
and then out of the blue,
Ford wrote to us and said,

"We're introducing the new
Mondeo." We didn't know it was coming.

- Who'd like to see it?
- Yeah.
Okay. Here it is.

- That's the old one there.
- No, that's the new Mondeo.

They say
it's got 1,500 new parts.

Yes, presumably, but they're
all exactly the same shape

as the old parts.
So it looks exactly the same.

- It's got a new radio. Hasn't it?
- It has got a new radio.

There's hundreds of bits
in there.

There's 1,500 parts in a
radio. That's exactly what it is.

The only thing that
probably is worth mentioning

is that you can now have it with
a direct petrol injection engine.

Sounds catastrophically
boring, I know.

But the fact of the matter is, is that at
low speeds, town speeds and what have you,

it uses much less petrol
than a normal petrol engine.

And the great... Stay awake.
The best thing is,

you don't have to
buy a diesel.

I know it's not
the most interesting car...

- No...
- ..in that range, but I still think the Mondeo,

if you compare it to
the rest of that class,

Mazda 6's of this world
and whatever,

- it's still a really good car.
- It is a very, very good car.
Not interesting.
It's not very interesting.

No, it is a good car. No, honestly,
I really do like the Mondeo.

I mean, I think I'd probably
buy a Renault Laguna

if I were after that kind of
mid-range, four-door saloon. You?

Yeah, I'd probably
have a Honda Accord.
But you'd have a Mondeo?

Yeah, definitely. But I'll tell
you what you could have,
if you want a free car,

this is good news
for all of us.

"If you want a free Vectra..."
Sorry, Jeremy.

- Well, it would need to be.
- Yes.
Uh, "Vauxhall are doing..."

I've got this right, I've
read it several times over.

If you ring
a telephone number,
Vauxhall will deliver to you,
to your house, a Vectra.
Drop it off,
you can drive around in it,

and 48 hours later
they'll take it away.
You don't have to buy it?

No, you don't buy it, this is to
get people test driving the Vectra,
so you telephone a number,

they drop the car off, and
you... That... That's brilliant!

So if you just want to go
and see granny or a girlfriend

in Manchester
and it's a 60 quid rail fare,

you can just ring them up,
they drop a car at your house,
drive it up there and back.

What if you wanna do
a bank job?

That's a better idea,
isn't it?

Or if you're just a broke student
going on a rave with your mates.

No, seriously, I wonder
how many they've got.

Well, I don't know.
Because presumably this is...

This is the launch of their campaign,
it's quite an important moment.

Somebody spent an awful lot of
time planning this and working on it.

The worst thing we could do is give
out the number, which is 08456775775.

Three and a half million
people watching this!

- Let's do it.
- If everybody rang tomorrow...
It's a free car for 48 hours!

See the Luton Telephone
Exchange... Poof!

You get a free car
for 48 hours!
That's brilliant value. Do it.
What have you got, James?

I've got something quite
interesting from Volvo.

Now, those big four-by-four
lifestyle things,

- the BMW X5, that's about 50 grand.
- Yeah.

- Range Rover, 50-51 grand.
- Yeah. Yeah.

- That VW Touareg thing you were driving the other week...
- Fifty grand for the V10.
Fifty grand, yeah?

The Volvo XC90, the same
sort of thing, you would agree?
Sounds like a bargain.

- It is a bargain.
- It is a bargain.

Until you get
some extras fitted.

They've come up with two rear
televisions, two screens, in truth,
and a DVD player.

- Yeah.
- You've been to Dixons, you men of the world,
how much does it cost?

Well, screens are about,
what, 150 quid.

- A hundred and fifty quid a telly.
- That's 300.
